text: Nitro tap. Clear golden. Easy going going grain nose. Flavor is sweet grainy malt with light honey graham cracker and a light grassy bitterness. Nitro really adds a nice dimension. Wouldnt have thought.

Tap at OSS. Nitro pour. Clean and easy, not unlike a Boddingtons or similar UK draught. Steady foamy off-white head. Smooth, cream golden malt. A little watery, not much depth. Hyper-sessionable light body. OK. Sublime. Simple. Brewhouse bland aroma. OK.

Draft at HopCat Madison. Pours crystal clear gold with Guinness style foam that slowly settles - mesmerizing. Aroma of light vanilla, straw. Taste is peppery, moderately bitter, silky smooth creamy mouthfeel. Very nice.

On tap. Golden pour with the expected thick head, which does not go away. not much aroma - slightly astringent and floral. Flavor is a good balance of malt and some floral hops. Definitely some resin in the finish. Thick, silky mouthfeel, as expected. Not a huge fan of the style, but good for what it is.

Draft. Clear copper color with thick white nitro head; thick lacing. Subtle malt aroma. Smooth, creamy malt upfront. Pleasant bitter finish with slight resin.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Backlog rating on 8-15-2012 at 800 Degree Three Fires (Fort Wayne, IN) This nitro beer pours a lot of foam and then is reduced to a small creamy smooth white head that is fully lasting, transparent yellow body, very little carbonation observed, and a generous amount of lacing adorns my glass. The aroma is biscuits, malt, hops, and a suggestion of fruitiness. The flavor is sweet, malt and mild hops. The mouthfeel is smooth and this beer is medium bodied. This beer has mild English hops and is very quaffable.

[Tap] Pours a clear brown color without much head. Nose is of chalky malts and maybe a hint of nuttiness. Toasted breads, light grass and caramel in the taste. Smooth mouthfeel and low carbonation levels. Nice and sessionable.
On nitro at WOB. Creamy gold pour with a thick white head. Light earthy citrus hop aroma. Creamy malt body with a touch if hops. Very good.

Tap. Yellow pour with a monster white nitro head. Slightly bready, mostly a little grassy hop kick late. Easy drinking. Nitro was a good call with this to add a visual and palate element to an otherwise kind of ho-hum beer.

This draft brew poured a small sized head of cascading foam white colored bubbles that were and left behind a uncarbonated transparent orange colored body and an excellent lacing. The weak aroma was hoppy and malty. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of creamy smooth malt. An OK brew just nothing special.

Nitro at Three Fires. Creamy lactic malt aroma. Deep golden with a moderate creamy white head, thick lacing. Biscuity malt with a light grassy hop finish. Medium creamy body, flat carbonation, slightly dry finish. Not bad for a cream ale.

Smells like a lager but not much else. Poured on tap golden in color with white nitro thick foam head. Taste nice bitterness, low hoppyness, tastes like a lager not an ale. Medium to thin but the nitro helps thicken it. Not bad but not great.

Not much of a scent on this beer. It has a rather light roast taste and it is pretty creamy. It is really drinkable, nice on a hot day.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: DEC 11, 2015 At Fountainhead. Much better than other creamy nitro ales. Big creamy white head. Light bodied by not watery. Some bitterness from the hops. Serving: Nitro draft.

On nitro at Stub & Herb's - thick white head that won't go away. Nose is floral hops. Mouthfeel is fantastic, soft and creamy. This is what I imagine an English pub ale should be. A nice balance of malt and bitterness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draught at Local Option. Clear amber - white head. Ok malty. Toasted. Bisquit. Fruity. Nice fruity hoppy. Almost no bitterness. Grassy. Grape fruits. Light grapes. Citrus.
Smooth, creamy " English session bitter". It isnt too bad, a step up form boddingtons.

Sampled from the tap at the Milwaukee brewpub. Pours a hazy orangish gold with a white head that lasts throughout the beer and laces thickly. Aroma has a light perfume note with a bit of flora and some earthy sweet grains. Flavor was a bit thin with light fruit, sweet grains and a bit of earthy grass.

On tap at Craft in Middleton, WI - Pours hazy brown with a big fluffy off-white head. Nose is herbal, lightly grassy hops over a lightly toasted malt base. Taste is roughly the same--very smooth malt, lightly toasted and bready, with a herbal, grassy, lightly spicy hop profile. Bites a little bit on the finish. Full and very creamy--mouthfeel is excellent in this one. Wasnt expecting much, but this was pretty impressive.

Super pale razor-clear amber pour with a perfect creamy nitro head.  Aroma is very light pale malt, a hint of caramel balanced by a mild dry hop resin/wood nose (Fuggles or Goldings?).  Taste is biscuit, grain tannin, woody hop resin, caramel.  Body is medium, super creamy from nitro, mild bitter dry hoppy finish.  Overall, extremely drinkable, best by far Ive had yet form Hinterland.

On nitro at Hinterland Green Bay.  Clear amber with a creamy bone colored bonnet and thick nitro style lacing.  Aroma is fairly mild with malt and light fruit.  Taste is smooth and creamy with fruit, light smoke, toasted malt, pale malt and a touch of floral and woodsy hops.  Mild bitter finish.

Tapper was mid-gold color with nice foamy lace.  Aroma was slightly sweet with a malty backbone.  Taste was of malt, some corn/grains, pear hints and a moderate hop finish.  Palate was decent.  Overall, pretty decent, but I was anticipating something smoother and less hoppy for a cream ale.
user_location: Town of Maple Creek, Wisconsin, USA

text: Clear gold orange, creamy white foam.  Aroma is fruity sweet malt.  Taste is a big dulled by the nitro, but a nice solid fruitiness, apples, sweet malts.  Interesting to have a cream ale on nitro.

Enjoyed during a closed door tasting session in Green Bay with the brewer, Joe Karls. Poured a clear, gold/amber with an off white, silky, nitro head and a thick, lasting, curtain of lacing. The aroma was slightly bready malt and light fruit sweetness. The flavor added to these a nice subtle hop bitterness, with a pleasant, creamy mouthfeel throughout. Very drinkable and refreshing.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 A light golden color with lots of effervescence and abundant amounts of lacing.  Aroma is light floral hops and some light lemongrass along with some mild grain flavor.  Taste is much the same with a bit of cereal grain and fruitiness coming in at the finish.  Nothing exciting but it is an enjoyable beer.

One of my favorites from Hinterland. It had a nice bright golden colour, very creamy in texture, smooth feel in the mouth, not overly carbonated, but pleasent. flavors are rich and bright, very smooth.

Pours a golden amber color with a large white head with very complex lacing.  Aroma with slightly hoppy, citrus, with some caramel tones.  This is a very smooth drinking brew.  Taste is creamy, citrus, caramel, and slightly hoppy.

On nitro-draught at the brewpub in Green Bay, Wisconsin. Pours a golden pale amber brew with a creamy white head that has excellent lacing from the nitro charged. Aroma of light caramel malt, citrus zest and some floral hops. Taste is smooth and creamy, medium bodied with a good balance of malt and critus zest hops. Finish is smooth with a mild and lingering bitterness. Nice touch with the nitro charge.
On tap at the berwery.  Very good creamy mouthfeel on this gold colored beer.  Faint floral hops in the malty nose.  Caramel and malt in the body with a light hoppy finish.

On tap at Hinterland.  Poured a cler, bright golden with sticky bubbles on the bottom and a very well-retained cap of creamy white head.  The aroma was of soft drier floral notes upfront with deep caramel and light citrusy sweetness behind.. pleasant all-around.  Sweet caramel and fruity base with mild floral, pine, and citrus hoppage.. nice balance.. a touch light.  Creamy on the palate with a lighter body and well-placed bitterness around the sides.
Dark golden to amber color with a small dense off white head. Toasted white bread aromas with a hint of hopsack. Very english pale type brew. Maris otter and hopsack abound.

Full white head (on nitrogen) that lingered with complex lacework.  Perfect amber color, strong malt aroma.  Taste of caramel malt and biscuits.  Wonderful on the palate, creamy and mildly bitter.  Only the slightest of hoppiness. Super.   Went very well with the Pacific oysters.
